title: MLB commissioner Rob Manfred on Astros controversy: 'We have to be tremendously concerned'
text:
CLOSE SportsPulse: USA TODAY Sports' Nancy Armour provides her opinion on the controversial situation surrounding the Houston Astros and executive Brandon Taubman. USA TODAY

HOUSTON — Major League Baseball commissioner Rob Manfred was careful in his words Wednesday, but it was clear he was agitated by the Houston Astros’ actions, and embarrassed by assistant GM Brandon Taubman’s expletive-filled tirade towards a group of female reporters.

MLB has launched an official investigation into the matter Wednesday, interviewing Taubman, Astros’ staffers and the three reporters who overheard the tirade.

“I’m really concerned at this point about the underlying substance of the situation,’’ Manfred said, “and what the atmosphere was, how it came to be. That’s my focus right now.

“We pride ourselves on providing an inclusive, harassment-free environment in all the various aspects of our business. I think it’s a core value for baseball and I think we have to be tremendously concerned when we have an incident that attracts this much attention.’’

Taubman, celebrating the Astros’ American League pennant-clinching Game 6 on Saturday, yelled: “Thank God we got (Roberto) Osuna! I’m so (expletive) glad we got Osuna!” towards the three reporters who were standing in the team’s clubhouse.

Osuna was acquired in July 2018 while he was serving a 75-game suspension for violating Major League Baseball’s Joint Domestic Violence, Sexual Assault and Child Abuse policy.

Osuna, who was arrested in Toronto for allegedly assaulting his girlfriend, and the mother of their 3-year-old son, accepted his suspension without appeal. The charges were withdrawn last September when Osuna entered into a peace bond in Canadian court.

Taubman, who has refused to comment on the incident, issued a statement that read: “I used inappropriate language for which I am deeply sorry and embarrassed. In retrospect, I realize that my comments were unprofessional and inappropriate. My overexuberance in support of a player has been misinterpreted as a demonstration of a regressive attitude about an important social issue.”

Astros GM Jeff Luhnow has also declined comment, save for answering one question in an appearance on the team’s flagship radio station – and has not made himself available to reporters.

“What we really don’t know is the intent behind the inappropriate comments he made,’’ Luhnow told SportsTalk790. “We may never know that because the person who said them and the people who heard them, at least up to this point, have different perspectives.’’

The only member of the organization who has publicly commented to reporters is Astros manager A.J. Hinch, who has addressed the issue the past two days, despite not witnessing the incident.

“For me, I feel responsible for the clubhouse,’’ Hinch said Wednesday. “I feel responsible for everything that goes on down here. I consider myself a leader. I cherish this place. I cherish our players and everything that goes on. I was just being the manager of the club here down here in the clubhouse. …

“No one, it doesn’t matter if it’s a player, a coach, a manager, any of you members of the media, should ever feel like when you come into our clubhouse that you’re going to be uncomfortable or disrespected.”

Manfred won’t know whether Taubman’s actions will warrant discipline until MLB officials complete their investigation, but they were not consulted when the Astros put out a statement calling the story “misleading and completely irresponsible” and saying it was an “attempt to fabricate a story where one does not exist.”

“There will be a conversation with the club at the end of the investigation,’’ Manfred said, “and as often the case, we’ll make a decision working with the club as to how, who should handle it. At the end of the day, he is an Astros employee.

“In general, it is my view that you want to get all the facts, want to be as thorough as you possibly can, understand what the whole situation (is). Once you get there, you want to get it all behind you.’’

Manfred speaks to reporters prior to Game 2 of the World Series. (Photo: David J. Phillip, AP)

Manfred, who met with a small group of reporters after the Hank Aaron Award press conference before Game 2, also addressed the notion that MLB is using different baseballs than the regular season.

Baseballs have traveled significantly less this postseason, according to research by Baseball Prospectus, and supported by St. Louis Cardinals manager Mike Shildt, who said that their analytics team discovered that baseballs were traveling 4 ½-feet less than the regular season.

There’s a 6% decrease in homers hit per game, 2.61, compared to the record-setting rate of 2.78 in the regular season. Curiously, the ball traveled further in the 2017 postseason, with a home-run increase of 12% from the regular season to 2.82 homers per game, the first season players strongly believed the ball was juiced.

“I can tell you one thing for very certain, just like every other year,’’ Manfred said, “the balls we used in this postseason were selected from lots that were used in the regular season.

“There is no difference in those baseballs.’’

Yet, when you talk to players and coaches this postseason, and they’re convinced there’s a dramatic difference.

“We try to be really disciplined about this,’’ Manfred said. “I think an analysis based on large sample sizes – meaning season-long samples – is really the most reliable research. We’re going to have that report from scientists.

“Just remember, you’re backing into a drag number, and when you have a large sample, variables like weather and who’s pitching, that all washes out in a very large sample. When you start picking three days in the postseason when the weather’s different and you have the very best pitching in the game, it becomes less reliable.’’

Manfred also said that no decision has been made on a reported proposal that MLB wants to eliminate 25% of the minor league teams, dropping the total number from 160 to about 120, in hopes of prioritizing the upgrading of minor league facilities.

“We had three preliminary meetings and then a round in the press that was pretty clearly orchestrated,’’ Manfred said. “Some of what’s been out there is inaccurate.

“I think the important points of this, there’s an economic system in minor league baseball where we heavily subsidize what goes on in minor league baseball. We are more than prepared to continue to do that. Against that backdrop, I don’t think it’s unreasonable of us to expect that we have facilities that are first-class for some of the greatest athletes in the world, that we have league alignments that are reasonable and not onerous for those same athletes.

“I think over the long haul, minor league baseball will be at the table and prepared to discuss those things. I see this as a momentary interlude.’’

Manfred shrugged off the idea that losing minor-league baseball in small markets could possibly hurt MLB.

“We agree that minor league baseball is an entrée into fandom,’’ Manfred said. “If you look at the discussions we had, many of those franchises average less than 2,000 people a game. They’re not really major drivers of attendance in the minor leagues.

“Our preference was never to reduce numbers. It was to get to first-rate facilities. If we can’t get to first-rate facilities, I’m not sure it makes sense for us to send people to play in facilities that are inadequate, and continue to subsidize those inadequate facilities."
